body: How easily can you reproduce the issue?
On install, essentially. Just installed and it doesn't work. :(

> This issue is very easy to produce and very easy to fix.

Any chance you could submit a pull request? That’ll help keep it at the top of my TODO list.

Thanks for the extra feedback either way.
Is that the best way to solve it. Does ['',0] make sense?

I’ve no idea, not looked into it yet. But if there’s a potential fix, then seeing exactly what change it means & ensuring that it passes the test suite would be a great start. A failing test case that it resolves would be even better. Hopefully I’ll be in a position to review stuff on Monday and release a fix.

What would be a minimal consumer example to reproduce this in a channels project? I've tried re-producing using the [multichat](https://github.com/andrewgodwin/channels-examples/tree/master/multichat) example, but didn't see any issues in my initial test.

Maybe it needs to be run with Gunicorn behind a unix socket connection.
Where does sockname get set? I couldn't find it getting set anywhere.

On Fri, Nov 30, 2018, 7:17 PM Jordan Eremieff <notifications@github.com
wrote:

> What would be a minimal consumer example to reproduce this in a channels
> project? I've tried re-producing using the multichat
> <https://github.com/andrewgodwin/channels-examples/tree/master/multichat>
> example, but didn't see any issues in my initial test.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/encode/uvicorn/issues/242#issuecomment-443378739>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AB8pv6HbmJEXcXro6oAplOwEq8wix_h9ks5u0cqAgaJpZM4YT8L9>
> .
>

Its really easy to see how this is happening. `get_local_addr(transport)` returns None if the sockname key is not set. You just follow that code to where it gets set on the scope and its taking [0] from None. What should that function return when sockname is not set (it appears to never be set) instead of None?

What is a simple means of reproducing the issue in order to debug/test the solution? According to the ASGI [spec](https://asgi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/specs/www.html#websocket), the  `server` field is optional and defaults to `None`. It may be clear what is happening, but we need a way to reproduce the behaviour to determine a generic solution.

issue.title: Fix issue with websockets logging

repository.name: uvicorn
repository.description: An ASGI web server, for Python. 🦄

issue.body:
Two issues here:

* We weren't allowing for the `None` case.
* We should be logging the *client* address, not the server.

Closes #242
Closes #254
